bibl.idno: The Papers of Henry Rose Carter [manuscript] ; HEALTHSCI MS-10.

bibl.title: Letter from L. O. Howard to Joseph A. LePrince, February 15, 1922

div1.p: Howard identifies the mosquitoes, captured in a hotel's coatroom in Carbondale, Illinois, as males of the yellow fever mosquito.

div1.head: Letter from L. O. Howard to Joseph A. LePrince, February 15, 1922
div1.opener:
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE,
BUREAU OF ENTOMOLOGY,
WASHINGTON, D. C.
February 15, 1922.
Mr. J. A. LePrince,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Room 17, Court House,
Memphis, Tenn.
Dear Mr. LePrince:
div1.p:
The mosquitoes which you sent with your undated memorandum
and which were taken in the coat room of the Hotel Roberts at
Carbondale, Ill. on January 19th prove to be all males of the
yellow fever mosquito, which Doctor Dyar insists now be called
Aäedes aegypti L. (the calopus of the Monograph). I note that
you say in your memorandum, “Others were biting.” It is too
bad that you did not send me specimens of those that were biting.
Doctor Dyar thinks that these mosquitoes must have been breeding
in the warm rooms of the hotel all winter. They must have come
in on the person of some traveler from the south, away back in
the fall. Doctor Dyar comments that the males were evidently
swarming in the evening, and as they like to swarm near a person
they were easily caught.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, L.O. Howard Chief of Bureau.
loh-wft
P. S. You will remember possibly that Busck found this species
breeding on the exposition grounds at St. Louis during August, 1904;
and of course the records of early yellow fever cases along the Ohio
River, to say nothing of the old Philadelphia epidemic and the cases
north of the Canadian border, show how these artificially transported
specimens may breed during the summer months away beyond their limits
as annual species.
Le Prince
Steg in Ill.
in January/22
